text:

We encountered unavailability issues that we believe could be at the cloud provider level.

Show HN: Small Ears – A Newsletter focused on small artists
text:
Small Ears is the place where you (and your friends) can hear about musics that you probably don’t know.

The goal of this newsletter is to get out of the “top of the chart” and help you discover people that put their heart into the music without getting the same exposure as popular artists.

Show HN: Humanize the web again with Hey Homepage
text:
Hello HN,

TLDR: We want to humanize the web again. So we built a do-it-yourself website builder with social functions.

Your website and domain are your personal platform. Just as the web is already social media. Loaded with a simple but powerful website tool, you can express yourself and explore others. Design your style and publish your content with a do-it-yourself website builder. Anybody can do it, amateurs and professionals alike. There are multiple software tools out there to assist.

Our own tool Hey Homepage [1] comes with a lot of extra functions. Share regular long form content on a blog. Sell physical goods, digital files and service appointments with a webshop. And use a flexible form to ask the info you want. Visitor stats are done without external software that tracks your visitors. Also no cookie banner. Our websites are internet friendly.

The cool new Really Social Sites (RSS for short) function enables your website to connect with other websites so you can stay up to date. You decide what sites to connect to and there are no recommendations. You are the algorithm, our tool just makes it easy and fun again.

Right now, we offer sites as a service. Subscribe to our starter package or request a trial first. We plan to open source in the future, so devs and nerds can get a license to selfhost the source code. Join the wait list if you're interested.

Best regards, Bram from Hey Homepage

P.S. We want to humanize the web again. We're not alone in this. We've seen all kinds of inspiring initiatives on HN the last years. From search engines like Marginalia to personal websites like Micro.blog. And we're not even counting all the interesting RSS feeds we gathered from all of you. Thank you all!

[1]: https://www.heyhomepage.com/

Ask HN: Replacement for 2010 MacBook Air?
text:
I simply love my MacBook Air (2010, tapered body). The keyboard, the weight, the shape, the trackpack.

Although I still use it (with Linux) and have a couple of top-spec daily drivers, I feel it's a matter of time it will "join the bleedin' choir invisible". Which modern laptop will provide a similar feel, weight and size?

It doesn't need to be Apple, of course and lower end specs (RAM, CPU) are fine too, since I'll use it mostly for light work.
